SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes how the author develops the central idea that sense of smell is an important part of memory recall in ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù?

A.Choice: by describing experiments scientists have done about memory and smells

B.Choice: by sharing stories about how smells triggered memories for certain people

C.Choice: by illustrating a specific example of how a smell triggered a memory in an individual

D.Choice: by explaining the scientific connection between the human brain and the sense of smell

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Read the quotation from paragraph 5 of ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù

:ibox:‚ÄúI believe that the Proust phenomenon can be subtly redefined,‚Äù Herz says. ‚ÄúOdors may trigger a memory of uncommon emotional power, it is true. But the vividness of memory‚Äîits sensation of accuracy‚Äîis an illusion created by that rush of emotion.‚Äù
How does the author use the quotation to support her argument in the passage?

A.Choice: to add to the Proust phenomenon experience by stating odors retrieve old memories

B.Choice: to support the Proust phenomenon experience by agreeing that odor retrieves old memories

C.Choice: to modify the Proust phenomenon experience by combining odors and emotions to retrieve old memories

D.Choice: to disprove the Proust phenomenon experience by stating that emotions are what retrieves old memories

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Identify one claim made by the author in ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù

A.Choice: Smells bring back childhood fears.

B.Choice: Smell has a special connection to feelings.

C.Choice: Vision is the most important sense for memory recall.

D.Choice: Findings of past research are incorrect and need to be revised.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúThe same sights, sounds, and odors that are present when we learn something new help us to recall it later.‚Äù (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: ‚ÄúOdor cues brought back older memories‚Äîthings that happened when the respondents were ages 6 to 10.‚Äù (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: ‚ÄúSubjects rated their smell¬≠cued memories as more emotional and richer in detail than the word¬≠ or picture-stimulated ones.‚Äù (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: ‚ÄúRegardless of whether they had smelled the odor or just heard the word, people were no more accurate in remembering the painting.‚Äù (paragraph 4)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.

D.Choice: ‚ÄúOdors are processed and memories are retrieved (but not stored) in the brain‚Äôs right half.‚Äù (paragraph 5)

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how two or more authors writing about the same topic shape their presentations of key information by emphasizing different evidence or advancing different interpretations of facts.
Content: How do the authors of ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù and ‚ÄúQ&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?‚Äù differ in their emphasis of information on the nose?

A.Choice: In ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù the author acknowledges a psychological connection, while the author of ‚ÄúQ&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?‚Äù exposes failed past inquiries.

B.Choice: In ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù the author provides an explanation of a phenomenon, while the author of ‚ÄúQ&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?‚Äù explains a theory written by Plato.

C.Choice: In ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù the author describes anecdotes, while the author of ‚ÄúQ&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?‚Äù provides data from research and lingering questions.

D.Choice: In ‚ÄúBeam Me Up, Smell¬≠ie!‚Äù the author points out the strength of senses, while the author of ‚ÄúQ&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?‚Äù provides a detailed description on the future of nasal research.

D.Choice: ‚Äú‚ÄòI‚Äôve got a habit of being outspoken and folks mustn‚Äôt mind it.‚Äô‚Äù (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Determine an author‚Äôs point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: How do paragraphs 1‚Äì3 support the author‚Äôs purpose?

A.Choice: The paragraphs describe a scientist‚Äôs interest in studying ocean life.

B.Choice: The paragraphs introduce a scientist as well as the topic of the interview.

C.Choice: The paragraphs pose several questions that are answered later in the passage.

D.Choice: The paragraphs indicate reasons why the reader may be interested in the topic.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:You get a sense that these animals not only know where they are but they know where they‚Äôre going in this big ocean.
What additional quotation supports the inference that the author makes in the sentence?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúBut animals see it very differently, and that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs useful to send fleets of animals out with tags on them.‚Äù (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: ‚ÄúBy combining tag data with oceanographic data, we get to see how animals perceive the ocean, . . .‚Äù (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: ‚ÄúSometimes they‚Äôll get into an eddy, which is a big circulation pattern that can be 100 km across, . . .‚Äù (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: ‚ÄúThey get pushed around by strong currents, but then they‚Äôll travel back to resume their trajectory.‚Äù (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: In paragraph 2, Jeff Polovina states, ‚Äú‚ÄòThe tags allow us to see tracks in the ocean.‚Äô‚Äù Which quotation from the passage supports the statement?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúWe look out on the ocean and see this homogenous expanse.‚Äù (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre following well¬≠defined paths.‚Äù (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: ‚ÄúThat front separates a nutrient¬≠rich mass of water to the north from nutrient¬≠poor waters to the south, . . .‚Äù (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: ‚Äú. . . we used to think that whale sharks mainly used the shallow surface layer of the ocean.‚Äù (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:They get pushed around by strong currents, but then they‚Äôll travel back tÕüoÕü ÕürÕüeÕüsÕüuÕümÕüeÕü ÕütÕühÕüeÕüiÕürÕü ÕütÕürÕüaÕüjÕüeÕücÕütÕüoÕürÕüy.
What is the meaning of the phrase tÕüoÕü ÕürÕüeÕüsÕüuÕümÕüeÕü ÕütÕühÕüeÕüiÕürÕü ÕütÕürÕüaÕüjÕüeÕücÕütÕüoÕürÕüy as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: to travel off course

B.Choice: to become lost in the ocean

C.Choice: to arrive at a specific location

D.Choice: to continue on the same path

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What does the author‚Äôs use of ‚Äúshoot‚Äù in paragraph 17 illustrate about the fish?

A.Choice: It explains the different depths in which the fish forage in their search for food.

B.Choice: It indicates the speed at which the fish move from one depth of the water to another.

C.Choice: It shows that moving from one depth to another while looking for food is dangerous for the fish.

D.Choice: It demonstrates that the fish are releasing food as they move between different depths of the water.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 18.

:ibox:Different species seem to be pÕüaÕürÕütÕüiÕütÕüiÕüoÕünÕüiÕünÕüg the vertical depth structure in the ocean, each foraging on different species in a different depth range, so that they‚Äôre not all at the same depth competing for the same resources.
What is the meaning of pÕüaÕürÕütÕüiÕütÕüiÕüoÕünÕüiÕünÕüg as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: defining

B.Choice: hiding

C.Choice: layering

D.Choice: registering

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does the author‚Äôs use of the interview format aid in the understanding of the passage?

A.Choice: It allows the author to introduce various types of sea life and talk about their habitats.

B.Choice: It offers a clear understanding of the relationship between sea creatures and humans.

C.Choice: It provides steps that the reader can take in order to conduct research about ocean life.

D.Choice: It introduces an expert who gives examples of how animal tagging and satellite imaging lead to discoveries.

SubTopics: Determine an author‚Äôs point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: What is the author‚Äôs point of view about tagging different species of ocean animals for data?

A.Choice: The author disapproves of the tags because they cannot track different species effectively.

B.Choice: The author approves of the tags because he believes it is important to help conserve the different species.

C.Choice: The author disapproves of the tags because they provide false information on the swimming patterns of different species.

D.Choice: The author approves of the tags because he assists with the research and has already tagged hundreds of different species.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing each medium‚Äôs portrayal of the subject (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words).
Content: How does the photograph help develop an understanding of the satellite tags?

A.Choice: It shows how satellite tags are attached to animals.

B.Choice: It shows the effects of smaller satellite tags on smaller animals.

C.Choice: It shows where satellite tags are located on the loggerhead sea turtles.

D.Choice: It shows how satellite tags affect where loggerhead sea turtle migrate.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What did scientists learn after tagging loggerhead turtles on the beaches of Japan?

A.Choice: There were 400 loggerhead turtles on the beach.

B.Choice: Most of the Pacific Ocean had never been studied.

C.Choice: Loggerheads migrate after hatching on Japanese beaches.

D.Choice: There was an important feature of the ocean that was not known before.

Content: What effect would the information in the answer to Part A have on future scientific investigations?

A.Choice: Scientists will not explore that section of ocean anymore.

B.Choice: Scientists will decide that turtles are no longer endangered.

C.Choice: Scientists will look even more closely for unexpected results.

D.Choice: Scientists will assume all ocean animals migrate right after birth.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: What is a central idea of ‚ÄúSatellite Tagging‚Äù?

A.Choice: Scientists are constantly developing new ways to study animal habitats.

B.Choice: Scientists tag ocean animals to analyze the causes of certain migration patterns.

C.Choice: Scientists use satellites to create images of the ocean floor to learn about animal habitats.

D.Choice: Scientists utilize electronic tags and satellite images to learn how to better protect ocean species.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: Read the following prompt and write your complete response in the space provided.

:ibox:You have read ‚ÄúClover,‚Äù a passage about a man named Graham. Write an essay describing Graham‚Äôs interactions with his students. Analyze how the author describes Graham‚Äôs unique characteristics in the classroom and at home and how the students react to him. Provide key details and examples from the passage to support your response.

Your writing will be scored based on the development of ideas, organization of writing, and language conventions of grammar, usage, and mechanics.
Write your response for the prompt on the lines below.
